Chapter:
Algebras and their Actions
All the algebras considered in this package will be associative and commutative. Scalars belong to a commutative ring k with 1 \neq 0.
Why not a field? A group ring over the integers is not an algebra?
Commutative actions
If S and R are commutative k-algebras, a map
R \times S ~\to~ S, \qquad (r,s) ~\mapsto~ r \cdot s
is a commutative action if and only if the following five axioms hold:
k(r \cdot s) ~=~ (kr) \cdot s ~=~ r \cdot (ks),
r \cdot (s + s') ~=~ r \cdot s + r \cdot s', \qquad (so r \cdot 0_S = 0_S ~\forall~ r \in R),
(r + r') \cdot s ~=~ r \cdot s + r' \cdot s, \qquad (so 0_R \cdot s = 0_S ~\forall~ s \in S),
r \cdot (ss') ~=~ (r \cdot s)s' = s(r \cdot s'),
(rr') \cdot s ~=~ r \cdot (r' \cdot s), \qquad (so 1_R \cdot s = s ~\forall~ s \in S when R has a one),
for all k \in k, r,r' \in R, and s,s' \in S.
When I is an ideal in A then multiplication is an action. In the example the algebra is the group ring of the cyclic group C_6 over the field GF(5). The ideal is generated by v = () + (1,3,5)(2,4,6) + (1,5,3)(2,6,4). The generator r = (1,2,3,4,5,6) acts on v by multiplication to give the vector r \cdot v = (1,2,3,4,5,6) + (1,4)(2,5)(3,6) + (1,6,5,4,3,2).
gap> Ac6 := GroupRing( GF(5), Group( (1,2,3,4,5,6) ) );; gap> vecA := BasisVectors( Basis( Ac6 ) );; gap> v := vecA[1] + vecA[3] + vecA[5]; (Z(5)^0)*()+(Z(5)^0)*(1,3,5)(2,4,6)+(Z(5)^0)*(1,5,3)(2,6,4) gap> Ic6 := Ideal( Ac6, [v] );; gap> act := AlgebraActionByMultiplication( Ac6, Ic6 );; gap> act2 := Image( act, vecA[2] );; gap> Image( act2, v ); (Z(5)^0)*(1,2,3,4,5,6)+(Z(5)^0)*(1,4)(2,5)(3,6)+(Z(5)^0)*(1,6,5,4,3,2)
When R,S are commutative algebras and R acts on S then we can form the semidirect product R \ltimes S, where the product is given by:
(r,s)(r',s') ~=~ (rr',~ r \cdot s' + r' \cdot s + ss').
If B_R, B_S are the sets of basis vectors for R and S then R \ltimes S has basis
\{(r,0_S) ~|~ r \in B_R\} ~\cup~ \{(0_R,s) ~|~ s \in B_S\}
with defining products
(r,0_S)(r',0_S) = (rr',0_S), \qquad (r,0_S)(0_R,s) = (0_R,r \cdot s), \qquad (0_R,s)(0_R,s') = (0_R,ss').
Continuing the example above,
gap> P := SemidirectProductOfAlgebras( Ac6, act, Ic6 ); gap> Embedding( P, 1 ); [ (Z(5)^0)*(), (Z(5)^0)*(1,2,3,4,5,6), (Z(5)^0)*(1,3,5)(2,4,6), (Z(5)^0)*(1,4)(2,5)(3,6), (Z(5)^0)*(1,5,3)(2,6,4), (Z(5)^0)*(1,6,5,4,3,2) ] -> [ v.1, v.2, v.3, v.4, v.5, v.6 ] gap> Embedding( P, 2 ); [ (Z(5)^0)*()+(Z(5)^0)*(1,3,5)(2,4,6)+(Z(5)^0)*(1,5,3)(2,6,4), (Z(5)^0)*(1,2,3,4,5,6)+(Z(5)^0)*(1,4)(2,5)(3,6)+(Z(5)^0)*(1,6,5,4,3,2) ] -> [ v.7, v.8 ] gap> Projection( P, 1 ); [ v.1, v.2, v.3, v.4, v.5, v.6, v.7, v.8 ] -> [ (Z(5)^0)*(), (Z(5)^0)*(1,2,3,4,5,6), (Z(5)^0)*(1,3,5)(2,4,6), (Z(5)^0)*(1,4)(2,5)(3,6), (Z(5)^0)*(1,5,3)(2,6,4), (Z(5)^0)*(1,6,5,4,3,2), <zero> of ..., <zero> of ... ]
The SemidirectProductOfAlgebrasInfo(P) for P = R \ltimes S is a record with fields P.action; P.algebras; P.embeddings; and P.projections.
